Award.AwardTitle: Tracing the Origins of the Chaperonin (CCT) Complex in Eukaryotes

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through recent metagenomic analysis, it has become clear that the root of eukaryotes lies among microbes in the kingdom archaea. This project will explore the origins of an ancient protein family that assists with protein folding and stability, the chaperones (CPNs), to track their evolution into the eukaryotes. Recent identification of CPN encoding genes within the genomes of the so-called Asgard archaea will be utilized in order to gain structural insights into the biochemical function of these proteins, which have previously not been available due to the unculturability of the organisms. The project will utilize gene synthesis and expression of protein from metagenomic assembled genomes (MAGs). The main scientific benefit will be through the application of synthetic biology to gain insights into their ancestral protein folding functions and the development of eukaryotes from their prokaryotic ancestors. Proper protein folding is essential to all life processes and has implications in health and disease. Broader impacts will be through the training of a staff scientist and and undergraduates, as well as through outreach activities.

The main goal of the project is the discovery of quantitative biochemical insights into the functions of proteins in the newly discovered deepest branch of the CPN60 phylogenetic tree. Rapidly accumulating genome sequences and Single Amplified Genomes (SAGS) from the deepest branches of the archaea reveal lineages with increases in genome complexity and gene duplication. The investigators have identified divergent CPN60 genes in the ASGARD archaea which appear to be ancestral to the CCT subunits of the proteins found in extant eukarya. CPN60 from both the archaea and eukaryotes show cooperative allosteric effects in response to an obligate folding substrate such as tubulin. To explore the functional progression towards the eukaryotic CCT complex, this work will assess the function of these ancient CPN genes and the complex chaperones in terms of their ATP binding and ATPase activity and protein folding ability. Because there are also tubulin homologs in the Asgard Archaea Single Amplified Genomes, the project will address the exciting hypothesis that archaeal proteostasis was the ancestral proving ground for the detailed chaperone/client protein interaction networks found in eukaryotes, and will trace the functional advances of the chaperone complex from a putative ancestor with rudimentary biochemical features to the highly specialized and differentiated eukaryotic CCT complex shared by modern eukaryotes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:  Protein folding remains one of the crucial yet mysterious cellular functions. Chaperonins (CPNs) are ubiquitous, protein folding nanomachines that are required to fold and maintain many proteins in all cells. Group I CPNs are found in all bacteria and eukaryotic organelles that descended from Bacteria, and Group II CPNs occur in all archaea and in the eukaryotic cytosol.  A newly discovered cluster of chaperonins, named Group III, occurs in diverse bacterial groups as well as in a deep branching clade in Archaea belonging to the Phylum Thaumarchaeota (Techtmann and Robb, Archael like Chaperonins in Bacteria. PNAS 107(47):20269-74  . 2010). The thrust of the project was to study the ancestral HSP60 complex. The Thaumarchaeota are globally important as major contributors to marine and terrestrial nitrogen cycling. We developed the thermophile Nitrosocaldus cavascurensis (NCAV) as a model organism. We expressed its Group III CPN as an active 16-mer complex that is encoded from a conserved position within the urease operons of the ammonia oxidizing Archaea. The hypothesis we are exploring is that this ancient CPN60 will inform further study of the mechanisms determining client specificity in CPNs which is the key to the evolutionary transition to the eukaryotic CPN with its elaborate client protein services.

Intellectual Merit: Deeply branching archaeal CPN60 potentially ancestral to CPN homologs in both Archaea and Eukarya exist in the newly discovered archaeal phyla.  The eukaryal  16- mer complex has eight paralogous, nonidentical subunits per hemisphere with marked specialization of CPN subunits to recognize specific client proteins such as  tubulin and actin. Our study focused on the catalytic functions of the NCAV CPNs in terms of specialized protein substrate recognition to represent an evolutionary prelude to the eukaryotic protein folding pathway. In preliminary work we have established that recombinant CPN forms a 16-mer complex that is able to refold urease.  We will test urease folding reactions the NCAV Group II and Group III CPNs, and a CPN cochaperone called prefoldin (PFD) which is ubiquitous in archaea and eukaryotes. We will characterize the CPN and PFD complexes and urease by determining their crystal structures, substrate binding, Ni content and protein folding activities.

Broader Impacts: The project will extend the knowledge base of the vast diversity of unculturable Archaea which are basically microbial dark matter pending the application of molecular biology and biochemistry. The project will contribute understanding to the protein folding functions of an ancestral CPN and extend our insights into the evolution of the finely tuned allostery of the eukaryote CCT (CPN60) complex. Our recent description of the crystal structure of this novel CPN in a clade bridging Bacteria and Archaea chaperonins suggested that its folding mechanism lacked fine-tuned allostery and cooperativity. This proposed research  may represent the first protein in the Thaumarchaeota to be crystallized. The work will be done in an international collaboration with colleagues in Vienna and South Korea, and will engage US high school biology students, undergraduate students and a postdoctoral researcher. Outreach to high school AP biology students and high school teachers will be supported within the project by a specific budget item.
